Award.AwardTitle: Dynamic metallo-supramolecular oligomers stabilized by Cucurbit[8]uril connectors: self-assembly applied to combinatorial chemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
With the support of the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) program of the NSF Division of Chemistry, Prof. Masson investigates the recognition properties of water soluble metal-ligand complexes towards CB[n] and develops dynamic combinatorial approaches to preparing dynamic oligomers and polymers. Synthetic polymers are found in most objects used in everyday life. Polymers that spontaneously adjust their composition depending on their environment in water are of particular interest to Professor Eric Masson at Ohio University. His research group studies the formation and properties of a novel type of dynamic polymers in which the interchangeable building blocks are tied to one another with a pumpkin-shaped, hollow molecular ring called cucurbit[8]uril (CB[8]). The project has potential applications in biochemistry, as the dynamic polymers can interact with medically or biologically relevant materials such as proteins and cells, and in analytical chemistry, as the polymers can be used as sensors in quality control and drug detection applications. This project is multidisciplinary, and provides training to undergraduate and graduate students with a broad range of interests and talents, from organic synthesis, to biochemistry and statistical analysis. In addition, students are involved in the upgrade of an organic synthesis board game created by Professor Masson for computer tablets.

The building blocks of the dynamic oligomers targeted herein are metal-terpyridine complexes linked to CB[8]-binding units. The terpyridine ligands bear phenyl or naphthyl groups at the 4'-position to promote binding in the CB[8] ring. The terpyridine ligands are also functionalized with bio-inspired side chains (based mostly on amino acid residues) at the 4- and 4"-positions for interactions with the outer wall of CB[8] and for target recognition. The metal-ligand complexes are connected non-covalently via binding to the CB[8] rings. The outer wall of CB[8] participates de facto in the target recognition process once the metal-ligand/CB[8] oligomers are formed. This project involves (1) the preparation of a library of metal-ligand complexes (such as iron(II)-, ruthenium(II)- and iridium(III)-terpyridine) with a variety of pendent groups; (2) the assessment of their recognition properties towards CB[n]s and the interactions between the pendent groups with the outer convex surface of CB[n]s; and (3) the preparation and characterization of the metal-ligand/CB[8] dynamic oligomers in the absence and presence of biologically relevant targets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to prepare supramolecular dynamic polymers, i.e. polymers whose backbone is not secured by chemical bonds but can be affected by its surrounding environment. The building blocks of the polymers were (1) metal-ligand complexes as monomers, and (2) Cucurbit[8]uril (CB[8]) macrocycles as "glue" to link the monomers together. Cucurbit[n]urils (CB[n]) are pumpkin-shaped, hollow molecular hosts that can encapsulate various guest molecules into their cavities with extreme affinity in water. CB[8] is large enough to encapsulate two guests, and can therefore be used to link two chains together. As our building blocks bear two CB[8]-binding sites, a dynamic chain of building blocks is formed in the presence of the macrocycle. The connection is reversible and environment or stimulus-sensitive, as no covalent bond is formed between the two units inside CB[8].

The monomers were Iron and Iridium bis-terpyridyl complexes that were decorated with positive, neutral and negative side chains to affect their recognition towards CB[n] macrocycles, and therefore to affect the sequence of the building blocks in the dynamic polymers. We showed for the first time that the outer wall of the pumpkin-shaped macrocycles can interact with guest molecules, and that the sequence of the building blocks in the polymers is highly dependent on the charge of the building units. We also showed that Platinum terpyridyl acetylides do not assemble into dynamic polymers but form discrete 2:2 assemblies in the presence of CB[8] (i.e. assemblies with two Platinum building blocks sitting on top of one another and secured on both ends by two CB[8] macrocycles). Platinum terpyridyl attached to thiolates form a novel 2:1 "stacked" assembly with both Platinum centers sitting again on top of each other at one of the CB[8] rim, while leaving the other rim void of any interaction with the pair of guests. Identifying new ways for guest molecules to assemble with CB[n] hosts has been our key achievement during this funding period. This opens numerous opportunities for researchers in the field of supramolecular chemistry, who develop novel host-guest assemblies with applications ranging from drug design to the fabrication of stimulus-responsive materials.

Significant collaborative work has been carried out during this funding period, in line with NSF mission to increase partnerships within academia. Collaborative projects included the design, synthesis, and manipulation on a gold surface of a "nanowagon", a supramolecular assembly with an H-shaped chassis and four CB[7] wheels; the reduction of water into hydrogen gas upon irradiation of CB[8]-secured Platinum dimers; the characterization of our dynamic metallo-supramolecular polymers at the air-water interface; and the design of soluble, CB[n]-bound porphyrin analogs for oxygen transport and activation, an international collaboration with a research group at the University of Strasbourg, France.

Five graduate students and numerous undergraduate researchers have been involved in this project, as well as two post-doctoral associates, and exchange students from the universities of Toulouse and Haute-Alsace in France, and Leipzig in Germany. This project has allowed these coworkers to master state-of-the-art synthetic and analytical techniques in a chemistry laboratory. Thanks to our collaborative work, students have discovered completely new themes and facets of scientific research, that are not taught in a typical graduate or undergraduate chemistry curriculum.
